Description: Rim sherd of Chian, possibly Simple Animal Style, pottery chalice; white slip; interior: reserved band at rim, glazed streaky black below; part of lotus flower in added white outline with added red centre above two white bands; top of rim glazed; exterior: single dot frieze at rim; painted decoration consisting of goat (head, neck and back with red dots remaining), to right, looking back.
Curator's comments: Lemos describes the sherd as coming from a Wild Goat Style chalice in the style of the Würzburg chalices, but dated later than those chalices because she considers the style of the drawing to be debased and because of the elementary and isolated interior decoration (Lemos 1991, 72-3). The rim pattern on the sherd is not typical for the Wild Goat Style, but is common in the Simple Animal Style. Furthermore, the interior decoration on the sherd is not typical of the Wild Goat Style. Goats are not usually found in styles later than the Wild Goat Style, yet perhaps this is an exception. Similarly, boars die out with the Mature Animal Style, though one later example exists, see 1888,0601.467.
Bibliographic references: Lemos 1991 / Archaic Pottery of Chios. The Decorated Styles (p. 73, p. 235, no.142, pl.13) (Incorrectly registered as 1888.6-1.473a)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.1137) (phase 2)
